pageData.text: In this investigation, students will learn to identify and classify <button class='glossary-text'>rocks</button> as igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic based on the rocks’ composition and texture. Students will also learn how to interpret a rock’s physical characteristics to piece together how it might have been formed via the rock cycle.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Determining Sediment and Grain Size - 30 minutes 
Activity 2: Rock Type Identification - 60 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Determining Sediment and Grain Size - 30 minutes 
Activity 2: Rock Type Identification - 60 minutes
Overview Video

text: Define what a <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> is, and describe how to distinguish between a rock and a mineral.
Explain the different processes that form rocks in the rock cycle and how rocks are recycled to make new ones.
Identify the texture (grain size, shape, and orientation) and composition (mineral content) of a rock specimen to determine if it is igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic.
Devise and apply a hierarchical classification scheme that can be used to identify common rocks based on comparing observations to the rock dichotomous keys.

pageData.text: At Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona, the Colorado River has been slowly eroding a <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> formation, leaving high canyon walls and a way of travel back through time to the ancient past of the area. This area is primarily composed of sedimentary rock, which are formed in horizontal layers called strata. Each layer was formed by the primary sediments available at the time of their formation. These layers reflect the atmospheric composition, chemical reactions, water availability, and biological activity of the time, which affect the color, thickness, and composition of the layers. Because new sediment is added on the top, the deeper the layer the older the rock. Even when the layers have been disturbed by <button class='glossary-text'>erosion</button>, seismic activity, or geological uplift, the color and chemical composition can still often be traced through various rock formations. As organisms die, their remains may be trapped by the sediment and fossilized, providing another clue to what Earth was like in that geological period.  The layers can even be radioactively dated to determine the precise age of the rocks. As the river continues to deepen the canyon, new layers are revealed, and scientists are able to deepen our understanding of our planet’s history.

pageData.desc: Grand Canyon National Park showing the horizontal striped pattern of strata in the walls of the Grand Canyon.
pageData.altText: Grand Canyon National Park showing the horizontal striped pattern of strata in the walls of the Grand Canyon.

pageData.text: help form the foundations of the homes we live in, the roads we walk on, and the mountains we climb. A rock is a naturally occurring, inorganic solid composed of one or more aggregated minerals. For example, orthoclase, quartz, biotite, and amphibole are all minerals; however, if they combine into a single solid, then they become the igneous rock granite. Table 1 is a list of common rocks and the minerals that comprise them.

When identifying an unknown rock sample, you must characterize the texture and composition of the rock. Texture refers to the size, shape, and orientation of mineral grains that make up the rock. Grains can be macroscopic or microscopic in size; rounded, angular, or subangular (somewhat angular or slightly rounded) in shape; and randomly or preferentially oriented (arranged in the same direction). The composition refers to the minerals that constitute the rock. This investigation will focus on identifying the three different types of rocks—igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic—and how the different textures and compositions can aid with the identification of a specific rock.

Igneous Rocks Igneous are those that form from the cooling and solidification of melted (i.e., molten) rock material. The sub types of igneous rock include intrusive and extrusive. form deep within the earth’s crust. Due to the insulating effect of the earth’s crust, they take a long time to cool and solidify and thus tend to have large to very large mineral grains. These grains also tend to be angular to subangular in shape and are often oriented in a random pattern. Common intrusive igneous rocks include diorite (Figure 1), red granite (Figure 2), and gabbro (Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diorite
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diorite

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Red granite
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Red granite

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Gabbro
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Gabbro

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Extrusive igneous rocks</button> are formed at or near the surface of the earth from the cooling and solidification of lava (i.e., molten <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> at the earth’s surface). Because these rocks cool quickly, they tend to have microscopic mineral grains, which make determination of shape and orientation extremely difficult. However, these latter characteristics are typically much the same as those in intrusive rocks but at a microscopic scale. Common extrusive igneous rocks include pumice (Figure 4), obsidian (Figure 5), and basalt (Figure 6).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Volcanic rock
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Volcanic rock

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Obsidian
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Obsidian

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Basalt
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Basalt

Grains can be macroscopic or microscopic in size; rounded, angular, or sub-angular (somewhat angular or slightly rounded) in shape; and randomly or preferentially oriented (arranged in the same direction). This investigation will focus on identifying the three different types of rocks—igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic—and how the different textures and compositions can aid with the identification of a specific rock.

pageData.text: Sedimentary Rocks Sedimentary form from a complex process that follows four general steps: , , , and (Figure 7). Weathering starts the process and refers to the breakdown of previous rock material by physical and/or chemical means into small, transportable particles known as sediment. Source rocks for sediment can be igneous, metamorphic, and other sedimentary rocks. Sediment can vary in size from microscopic to ultramacroscopic. Table 2 presents some of the typical sediment sizes and their common names.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Labeled geological processes: weathering (break down of material), erosion (movements of sediment, and deposition (dropping of sediment to a new location).
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Labeled geological processes: weathering (break down of material), erosion (movements of sediment, and deposition (dropping of sediment to a new location).

pageData.text: Erosion is the second step in sedimentary rock formation. This involves the transportation of sediment from its source region to the area where it will be deposited. The principal agent of erosion is water; other agents include gravity, ice, and wind. The larger the sediment particles, the more work the agent of erosion must perform to move the sediment. For example, it takes a lower water velocity to move sand-size particles than it does to move cobblesize particles. Likewise, clay- or mud-size particles require much less water velocity to move than do sand-size particles.

Deposition is when particles being carried by the agents of erosion are expelled from the agent and laid down in everthickening layers of sediment. The catalyst for such expulsion and layering is usually the decrease in agent velocity (in the case of water, wind, and gravity) or melting (in the case of ice). Typical environments of deposition include lake and ocean bottoms, streambeds, glacial valleys and outwash plains, deserts (e.g., sand dunes), and the downslope segments of steep hills or cliffs (i.e., where gravity deposits material that then moves downslope under the influence of gravity).

The final step in sedimentary <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> formation is <button class='glossary-text'>lithification</button>, which is the hardening of layered sediment into rock. When sediment is first deposited, it is loose and unconsolidated, much like beach sand. However, as the layers of sediment build up over time, the bottommost layers become compressed by the weight of the overlying layers. This compression causes the sediment grains to pack closer and closer together. Sometimes this compression alone can cause the sediment grains to “stick” to one another. More often, however, water in between the sediment grains will deposit minerals that act as cement and glue to bind the particles, much like mortar in a wall binds brick. It is through these sub-processes of compaction and cementation that loose, unconsolidated sediment becomes lithified, or hardened, into sedimentary rock.

Sedimentary rocks come in a variety of textures, from very fine grained to very coarse grained. However, unlike igneous and metamorphic rocks, the individual grains of sedimentary rocks are typically not held together as tightly, which means a light tap on the table will usually result in some particles falling off. Furthermore, most sedimentary rocks are randomly oriented, with rounded grains. The rounded grains are the result of the <button class='glossary-text'>erosion</button> process. As grains are transported downstream, they collide with other grains, streambeds, and other hard objects, which causes angular corners and edges to be smoothed. By the time the particles are deposited, they have often lost their angular characteristics.

Compositionally, sedimentary rocks are largely composed of clay, quartz, and calcite, though other minerals are possible. One of the easiest ways to determine if a rock has calcite in it is to place a drop of weak acid, such as citric acid or vinegar, on it. These acids will react with the calcite (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) and cause effervescence, which is observed as bubbling in the drop of acid. Quartz is easy to identify as well because it has a hardness greater than glass. Finally, clay-rich rocks will most often display fine, laminate layering in a profile view (i.e., side view). Figure 8 shows how this layering might appear.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Profile view of layering in a clay-rich rock
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Profile view of layering in a clay-rich rock

pageData.question: What is the final step in sedimentary rock formation?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The final step in sedimentary rock formation is lithification, which is the hardening of layered sediment into rock.

pageData.text: Metamorphic Rocks Metamorphic are formed when other rocks—igneous, sedimentary, or even existing metamorphic rocks—undergo some change in physical characteristic and/or chemistry.

These changes are known as <button class='glossary-text'>metamorphism</button>. The agents of metamorphism are extreme heat; extreme pressure; and, to a lesser extent, chemically active fluids. The heat for metamorphism usually comes from the earth’s natural geothermal gradient (i.e., temperature in the earth’s crust increases with depth), magma beneath the surface, and/or frictional heat from platetectonic forces. It is important to note that the heat for metamorphism is never high enough to melt the rock. If the rock melts, then it becomes magma, and when the magma cools and solidifies, it becomes an igneous rock. Metamorphic heat causes the rock to become extremely hot, but it does not melt it.

The pressure for metamorphism has two principal sources. The first is simply depth. As you go deeper in the earth’s crust, the confining stresses (the stresses that are equal in all three dimensions) on rocks increase much like the pressure on your body increases as you dive deeper in a pool. The other is directional, or compressional stress, which is onedimensional stress caused principally by plate tectonics. Figure 9 illustrates these two types of stress for metamorphism: confining stress, which pushes on a rock from all sides, and compressional stress, which pushes on a rock along a single axis.

pageData.desc: Figure 9: Two principal stresses for metamorphism: confining stress, pushing the rock from all sides, and compressional stress, pushing on the rock along a single axis
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Two principal stresses for metamorphism: confining stress, pushing the rock from all sides, and compressional stress, pushing on the rock along a single axis

pageData.text: Chemically active fluids are extremely hotwater solutions that have a large amount of dissolved minerals in them. These solutions are usually found in association with underground magma chambers and thus are localized in their influence and not a primary agent of <button class='glossary-text'>metamorphism</button>. As these chemically active fluids are driven away from magma chambers, they take their mineral solutes and deposit them in other places. Along with the heat these fluids bring, the mineral solutes can metamorphose preexisting <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> by dramatically altering the rock’s chemical makeup.

When extreme compressional (or directional) stress is applied to a rock, it will often cause the elongated mineral constituents to align with their long axes perpendicular to the direction of stress (Figure 10). The result is a textural element called “preferred orientation,” and it evidences itself in specimens through a physical characteristic referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>foliation</button>. Foliation looks much like layering in sedimentary rocks, but it is not the result of depositional processes; instead, it is the result of stress in the crust. A way to differentiate layering from foliation is to see how easily the laminations part in the rock. If they part easily, then you may be dealing with a layered sedimentary rock. If the laminations are difficult or impossible to part, then you may be observing metamorphic foliation. (Figure 11 is an example of foliation in black shale.) This is not a foolproof test, but it is a good one for a budding geologist.

pageData.desc: Figure 10: Elongated mineral constituents aligned with their long axes perpendicular to the direction of stress, resulting in preferred orientation
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Elongated mineral constituents aligned with their long axes perpendicular to the direction of stress, resulting in preferred orientation

pageData.desc: Figure 11: Foliation in black shale
pageData.altText: Figure 11: Foliation in black shale

pageData.text: Metamorphic <button class='glossary-text'>rocks</button> can display a range of grain sizes; however, the grains in these samples will most often be fused together. Whereas sedimentary and igneous rocks usually possess grains that are easily distinguishable from one another in specimens, such is not the case with metamorphic rocks. The extreme forces of heat and pressure tend to weld these mineral grains in a three-dimensional array that makes distinguishing one grain from the next very difficult. In addition, metamorphic rocks are most often very hard and, like igneous rocks, possess tightly formed grains that do not easily break apart.

In terms of composition, metamorphic rocks comprise a vast spectrum of minerals that commonly include quartz, mica, and calcite. Quartz is harder than glass, so it is easy to identify against a glass streak plate. Mica grains typically appear as small flakes of what look like glitter, while calcite reacts with weak acids and displays the property of effervescence.

Rock Cycle The rock cycle conceptualizes the evolution, or life cycle, of a rock. Like nitrogen in the air or carbon in the soil, rocks are not in stasis. To the contrary, they are in a constant state of flux, or change. Rocks change from one type of rock to another over time (Figure 12). For example, an igneous rock can undergo , , , and to become a sedimentary rock. Likewise, a sedimentary rock can encounter extreme heat and pressure at depth in the earth’s crust and become a metamorphic rock. In fact, any rock can become any other type of rock, including its own type. So a metamorphic rock can undergo further heat and pressure and become a different type of metamorphic rock as well.

pageData.desc: Figure 12: The rock cycle, demonstrating how rocks change from igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic over time
pageData.altText: Figure 12: The rock cycle, demonstrating how rocks change from igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic over time

pageData.question: An igneous rock can undergo weathering, erosion, deposition, and lithification to become what type of rock?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Sedimentary rock is formed by the processes of weathering, erosion, deposition, and lithification.

pageData.question: A metamorphic rock can undergo further heat and pressure and become a different type of what rock?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Heat and pressure form metamorphic rock.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The rock cycle conceptualizes the evolution, or life cycle, of a rock.

img.alt: Figure 12: The rock cycle, demonstrating how rocks change from igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic over time

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning, you will obtain a sediment sample and print out the sediment gauge.  In activity 1, you will use the sediment gauge to determine the size of the particles in each of the samples.  In activity 2, you will determine the grain size, grain shape, and grain orientation. Then, you will tap the rock on a hard surface and observe grain cohesion. Next, you will add acid and observe effervescence. Then, you will scratch the glass plate with the rock and observe. Next, you will observe the rock for glittery appearance, layers, and foliation. Then, you will classify the rock based on its properties. Finally, you will repeat this until you have classified rocks A-F.

Then, you will tap the rock on a hard surface and observe grain cohesion. Next, you will add acid and observe effervescence. Then, you will scratch the glass plate with the rock and observe. Next, you will observe the rock for glittery appearance, layers, and foliation. Then, you will classify the rock based on its properties. Finally, you will repeat this until you have classified rocks A-F.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for each laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in this section and the Activity sections.
Acetic acid is a corrosive material. Use this near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with your skin or eyes.
pageData.desc: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigations. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: You find a rock composed of mica, quartz and garnet. This rock is most likely which of the following?
Which rocks form from the cooling and solidification of melted rock material?
Obsidian, pumice, and basalt are all types of which of the following?
Which of the following describes when particles being carried by agents of erosion are expelled from the agent and laid down in ever-thickening layers of sediment?
Which of the following looks much like layering in sedimentary rocks, but is not the result of depositional processes?
Which of the following materials will you need to supply yourself in order to complete this investigation?
If a drop of weak acid is placed on a rock and bubbles are produced, what mineral is likely present?
Which of the following is a safety consideration for this lab?

options.text: The hand lens has sharp edges.
Acetic acid can stain skin or clothing.
The rock samples are an environmental hazard.
Rock sample F is a choking hazard for pets or children.

Obtain a small sample of sediment from outside. Sediment is not the same as soil. Sediment does not contain organic material but can typically be found under topsoil or along a riverbed.
If you haven't already, print the Sediment Gauge (Figure 13) on standard 8½ × 11” paper.

pageData.desc: Figure 13: Sediment gauge to aid in identification of rock type, with images of grain size for pebbles, granules, coarse sand, medium sand, fine sand, silt, and clay; rounding (angular, sub-rounded, and well-rounded); poorly sorted and well sorted; and grains and matrix
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Sediment gauge to aid in identification of rock type, with images of grain size for pebbles, granules, coarse sand, medium sand, fine sand, silt, and clay; rounding (angular, sub-rounded, and well-rounded); poorly sorted and well sorted; and grains and matrix

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will determine the grain size of the particles in 4 sediment samples – 3 provided in the investigation and 1 that you collected.
Pour out a small sample (approximately the size of a dime) of each sediment type (clay, sand, pebbles, and the collected sample) onto a paper towel.

Use the Sediment Gauge to determine the grain size of each sample. Compare the size of the particles to the scale on the gauge to determine the approximate size of each particle. Record the size of the particles in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will evaluate 6 unknown <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> samples by their grain size, grain shape, grain orientation, reactivity with acid, luster, composition, laying, and <button class='glossary-text'>foliation</button> to determine the rock type.
Ensure you have six <button class='glossary-text'>rock</button> samples labeled “A” through “F.”
Record all information in Data Table 2 for sample A by following Steps 3–12.

Check the mineral grain size with the Sediment Gauge (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 13</button>). Are the grains clay (very fine grained), silt (fine grained), sand (coarse grained), or cobble (very coarse grained) in size?
Examine the grain shape. Are the grains angular, sub-rounded, or well-rounded? You may need to use a hand lens to see this.
Examine the grain orientation (sorting). Are the grains randomly oriented, or do they evidence preferred orientation?
Do the rock grains break apart easily? Tap the rock lightly on a hard surface. Do particles fall off?
Add a drop of acetic acid to the rock sample. Does any bubbling occur?
Check for the presence of quartz. Does the rock sample scratch the glass plate when dragged across it? If so, there might be some quartz present.
Examine the rock sample for a glittery appearance. If there is a glittery appearance, then mica is most likely present. Visible glitter with the naked eye means a large amount of mica is present.
Does the rock display layering? Remember, if the laminations part easily, it’s probably layering.
Does the rock display <button class='glossary-text'>foliation</button>? Remember, if the laminations do not part easily, it’s probably foliation.
Use Table 3 to determine the type identity for sample A. Choose the type that best fits the physical properties for the sample.

tableData.text: Hard to observe because grains are fused
Often, but it will only be a small percentage of the rock
Very common and will often comprise most of the rock

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 2–12 for samples B through F.

Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to the equipment kit.

data.title: Deposition
data.content: When particles being carried by the agents of erosion are expelled from the agent and laid down in ever-thickening layers of sediment

data.title: Erosion
data.content: The action of surface processes that removes soil, rock, or dissolved material from one location on the Earth's crust, and then transports it to another location where it is deposited

data.title: Extrusive igneous rock
data.content: A subtype of igneous rock that forms at or near the surface of the earth from the cooling and solidification of lava (i.e., molten rock at the earth’s surface)

data.title: Foliation
data.content: A physical characteristic that looks like layers due to deposition but is due to stress on the crust

data.title: Intrusive igneous rock
data.content: A subtype of igneous rock that forms deep within the earth’s crust

data.title: Lithification
data.content: The hardening of layered sediment into rock

data.title: Metamorphism
data.content: The formation of metamorphic rock from other rock types as they undergo some change in physical characteristic and/or chemistry

data.title: Rock
data.content: A coherent, naturally occurring solid consisting of an aggregate of minerals, pieces of pre-existing rocks, volcanic glass, or even a mass of organic material

data.title: Weathering
data.content: The breakdown of previous rock material by physical and/or chemical means into small, transportable particles known as sediment
